_metadata.description: Intervention mappings for PocketRescue Field Action Card system
sources: FAO Crop Water Information: Wheat, Barley, Maize, Sunflower, Potato
University Extension Services: Crop Management Best Practices
CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS)
International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT)

reasoning.HIGH_risk: Triggered when vegetation index < 0.18 with drought (precip < 5mm) or flood (precip > 40mm) conditions, or critical stress (index < 0.05). Interventions prioritize immediate action to prevent crop loss.
reasoning.MEDIUM_risk: Triggered when vegetation index is moderate (0.18-0.35) or conditions are borderline. Interventions focus on monitoring and preventive measures.
reasoning.LOW_risk: Triggered when vegetation index is healthy (> 0.35) and weather conditions are favorable. Interventions focus on routine management and documentation.

wheat._notes: Wheat is sensitive to drought stress during grain filling (Zadoks 60-90). Early detection allows for irrigation adjustment and nutrient management. Critical period: flowering to grain maturity. Sources: FAO Wheat Water Requirements, CIMMYT Wheat Management.

HIGH.action: Start moisture monitoring with tensiometers
HIGH.reasoning: Quantify soil water availability to guide irrigation decisions during critical grain-filling period

HIGH.action: Apply light foliar feed if nutrient-deficit suspected
HIGH.reasoning: Foliar application bypasses root uptake limitations under drought stress; improves grain quality

HIGH.action: Delay nitrogen top-up if drought risk high
HIGH.reasoning: Excess nitrogen under drought increases osmotic stress and reduces water use efficiency

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture levels regularly
MEDIUM.reasoning: Detect moisture trends early to optimize irrigation timing and prevent stress

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest and disease pressure
MEDIUM.reasoning: Stressed plants are more susceptible to Septoria, Fusarium, and aphids

MEDIUM.action: Plan irrigation schedule based on forecast
MEDIUM.reasoning: Align irrigation with weather forecast to maximize water use efficiency and reduce disease pressure

LOW.reasoning: Maintain standard management practices; monitor for maturity
Optimize nutrient uptake during favorable conditions; prepare for harvest
Build historical data for future crop planning and yield prediction

barley._notes: Barley is susceptible to powdery mildew and rust, especially under stress. Grain quality depends on timely maturity. Critical period: heading to grain maturity. Sources: USDA Barley IPM, University Extension Barley Management.

HIGH.action: Increase irrigation frequency if drought risk
HIGH.reasoning: Barley requires consistent moisture during grain filling to prevent shriveled grain

HIGH.action: Check for disease symptoms (powdery mildew, rust)
HIGH.reasoning: Stressed plants are highly susceptible; early detection allows for fungicide application

HIGH.action: Apply fungicide if disease pressure detected
HIGH.reasoning: Fungal diseases can reduce yield by 20-40% if untreated; timing is critical

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture and adjust irrigation
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain consistent moisture to support grain development and reduce disease pressure

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest activity
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for Hessian flies, armyworms, and other pests common in barley

MEDIUM.action: Plan harvest timing based on maturity
MEDIUM.reasoning: Harvest at optimal moisture (12-14%) to maximize grain quality and minimize losses

LOW.reasoning: Maintain routine monitoring and management practices
Track development to plan harvest timing and assess final yield potential
Ensure equipment is ready for timely harvest at optimal grain moisture

maize._notes: Maize is highly sensitive to drought during pollination (V12-R1). Corn borers and armyworms are major pests. Critical period: tasseling to silking. Sources: USDA Corn IPM, CIMMYT Maize Management.

HIGH.action: Implement emergency irrigation if available
HIGH.reasoning: Drought during pollination can reduce yield by 50%+ per day of stress; irrigation is critical

HIGH.action: Scout for corn borer and armyworm damage
HIGH.reasoning: Stressed plants are more susceptible to insect damage; early detection allows for treatment

HIGH.action: Apply insecticide if pest pressure high
HIGH.reasoning: Corn borers can cause 10-15% yield loss; armyworms can defoliate rapidly

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture and plan irrigation
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain consistent moisture during critical growth stages (V6-R3)

MEDIUM.action: Check for disease symptoms (leaf spots, rusts)
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for Gray Leaf Spot, Northern Corn Leaf Blight, and rust diseases

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest activity regularly
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for aphids, spider mites, and other pests that thrive under stress

LOW.reasoning: Maintain standard management practices; monitor for maturity
Ensure successful pollination and kernel set for optimal yield
Harvest at optimal grain moisture (15-20%) to minimize losses and maximize quality

sunflower._notes: Sunflower is moderately drought-tolerant but susceptible to head rot and fungal diseases. Critical period: flowering to seed maturity. Sources: FAO Sunflower Water Requirements, University Extension Sunflower Management.

HIGH.action: Increase irrigation if drought conditions
HIGH.reasoning: Drought during flowering reduces seed set and oil content; irrigation improves yield

HIGH.action: Scout for head rot and fungal diseases
HIGH.reasoning: Sclerotinia head rot can destroy entire heads; early detection allows for management

HIGH.action: Apply fungicide if disease detected
HIGH.reasoning: Fungal diseases can reduce yield by 30-50%; preventive treatment is more effective

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture levels
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain adequate moisture during seed development to maximize yield and oil content

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest damage (birds, insects)
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for sunflower beetles, stem weevils, and bird damage to developing heads

MEDIUM.action: Plan irrigation schedule
MEDIUM.reasoning: Optimize irrigation timing based on growth stage and weather forecast

LOW.reasoning: Maintain routine monitoring and management practices
Track seed development and maturity for harvest timing
Harvest when back of head turns brown (moisture ~12%) to maximize seed quality

potato._notes: Potato is highly susceptible to late blight (Phytophthora infestans) and early blight. Requires consistent moisture. Critical period: tuber initiation to bulking (V4-V8). Sources: CIP Potato Management, USDA Potato IPM.

HIGH.action: Increase irrigation immediately
HIGH.reasoning: Potato requires 400-600mm water; drought stress reduces tuber size and increases disease susceptibility

HIGH.action: Scout for late blight and early blight
HIGH.reasoning: Late blight can destroy entire crop in 7-10 days under favorable conditions; early detection is critical

HIGH.action: Apply fungicide if disease pressure high
HIGH.reasoning: Fungal diseases can cause 50-100% crop loss; preventive treatment is essential

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture and adjust irrigation
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain consistent moisture (60-80% field capacity) during tuber bulking

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest damage (Colorado beetle, aphids)
MEDIUM.reasoning: Colorado beetles can defoliate plants; aphids transmit viruses

MEDIUM.action: Check for disease symptoms regularly
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for early blight, late blight, and virus symptoms

LOW.reasoning: Maintain standard management practices; monitor for maturity
Track tuber bulking and assess final yield potential
Harvest when vines senesce (8-10 weeks after planting) to maximize tuber size and skin set

vegetables._notes: Vegetables include diverse crops (tomato, lettuce, cabbage, etc.) with varying water and pest management needs. General guidance applies to most vegetable crops. Critical period: flowering to harvest.

HIGH.action: Increase irrigation frequency immediately
HIGH.reasoning: Most vegetables require consistent moisture; drought stress reduces yield and quality

HIGH.action: Scout for disease and pest damage
HIGH.reasoning: Stressed plants are more susceptible to diseases and pests; early detection allows for treatment

HIGH.action: Apply protective spray if needed
HIGH.reasoning: Fungal and bacterial diseases can spread rapidly; preventive treatment is more effective

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture and adjust watering
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain consistent moisture to support growth and reduce disease pressure

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest and disease activity
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for common vegetable pests (aphids, whiteflies, caterpillars) and diseases

MEDIUM.action: Plan harvest schedule
MEDIUM.reasoning: Optimize harvest timing for quality and market readiness

LOW.reasoning: Maintain routine monitoring and management practices
Track growth and development for harvest planning
Harvest at optimal maturity for quality and shelf life

orchard._notes: Orchard crops (apple, citrus, stone fruits) have longer growing seasons and require consistent management. Critical period: flowering to fruit maturity. Sources: FAO Orchard Management, University Extension Fruit Crop Management.

HIGH.action: Implement irrigation if available
HIGH.reasoning: Drought stress during fruit development reduces fruit size and quality; irrigation is critical

HIGH.action: Scout for pest and disease damage
HIGH.reasoning: Stressed trees are more susceptible to pests and diseases; early detection allows for treatment

HIGH.action: Apply treatment if pest pressure high
HIGH.reasoning: Common orchard pests (codling moth, scale insects) can cause significant damage if untreated

MEDIUM.action: Monitor soil moisture and plan irrigation
MEDIUM.reasoning: Maintain consistent moisture during fruit development to support growth and quality

MEDIUM.action: Scout for pest and disease activity
MEDIUM.reasoning: Monitor for common orchard diseases (powdery mildew, scab, canker) and pests

MEDIUM.action: Plan nutrient application
MEDIUM.reasoning: Apply nutrients based on growth stage and soil analysis to support fruit development

LOW.reasoning: Maintain standard management practices; monitor for fruit maturity
Track fruit growth and assess final yield potential
Harvest at optimal maturity for quality and storage potential
